page.title: 11Transport - Canal
page.content: 17th and 18th century efforts were made to improve the river navigations that already existed which led to the building of the canals. In 1765 Josiah Wedgewood suggested a canal linking the ports of Hull and Liverpool. This was the start of the Trent and Mersey Canal. The first sod was cut in July 1766 by Wedgewood at Burslem. The Harecastle Tunnel south east of block 03760357 held up the completion of the canal until 1777. Originally the canal had 75 locks. The deplth of the canal was 5ft 6ins. There were 109 road bridges and five tunnels. The stretch of canal running through this block has 10 locks and an aquaduct. A fall in traffic is illustrated by these figures. {1848-1,341,622 tons}1888 - 1,139,098 tons{1933 - 318,086 tons } 1952 - 137,738 tons{1964 - 3,290 tons. The railway contributed to thi decline
